Dialogue.Line: We can't just leave her.
We're not leaving her, Jamie. It was her decision to stay. She'll be perfectly all right with the Harrises. Now don't worry so much.
I'm not, I'm just. Och, come on, let's go.
Well, where would you like to go?
I couldn't care less.
I was fond of her too, you know, Jamie.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: The Tardis dematerialises and Victoria's image fades from the screen. Later in the flight, Jamie is dozing in a chair.

Dialogue.Line: Jamie, we're landing. Jamie!
Huh?
We're landing!
Oh.
Let's have a look at the scanner, shall we?

Dialogue.Stage Direction: The scanner screen is blank.

Dialogue.Line: I thought you said we'd landed?
Oh, yes, we are, but I seem to have lost the picture. Let's try a little bit more power, shall we?
Are you sure you're pushing the right one?
Yes, of course I am. Look at the fault indicator, will you? It's round there on the left.
No, it's all right here.
No movement at all?
No.
Well, that's funny. The air's all right, the temperature's perfectly normal. There seems to be rather a lot of metal all around us
What? Oh, you know I can't hear you when you talk to yourself.
There we are, it's coming up now.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: A beautiful lake appears on the scanner.

Dialogue.Line: Hey, now that looks all right! Boy! Look at it. Hey, what's that?

Dialogue.Stage Direction: It's an exotic animal.

Dialogue.Line: The size of it.
Well, that's funny, it's changed to night now.
It's a wee bit quick, isn't it? Look, it's changed again. What's going on?
Oh dear. Those pictures aren't what's happening outside, I'm certain of that.
Why do they keep appearing then?
They're temptations.
Eh?
The Tardis is trying to warn us to get away from here to somewhere more pleasant. I must have pushed the wrong switch.
The red light's stopped flashing.
What?
Something must be wrong.
What? Well the power's overloading. The power lines are overloading!

Dialogue.Stage Direction: There's a flash.

Dialogue.Line: The fluid link's gone!
Doctor, look under here.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: A toxic gas is coming from the base of the console.

Dialogue.Line: The mercury's vapourising! We've got to get out of here, come on.
But how?

Dialogue.Stage Direction: The Doctor opens a small hatch beside the main doors to reveal a golden rod with capped ends attached to a bracket.

Dialogue.Line: Hold on to me.
What are you going to do?
Just hold on!

Dialogue.Stage Direction: The Doctor grasps the rod and pulls it from its holder. The console room walls shimmer and fold in on themselves. The doors are now open and the Doctor and Jamie get out.
A cramped compartment.

Dialogue.Line: Doctor, what's happened to the Tardis?
I disengaged the time vector generator.
The what?
Well once removed, it alters the size of the Tardis. The inside becomes an ordinary telephone box again. Come along, come and sit over here.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: The Doctor still has the rod, and Jamie is coughing a lot.

Dialogue.Line: If I hadn't have done, the mercury vapour would have killed us.
Where are we?
It looks like the motor section of some sort of rocket.
A rocket?
Oh, yes. There's an artificial gravity system, too.
What does that do?
Well, it's what keeps us on our feet, otherwise we'd be floating around.
Oh. There's no water around, is there?
Water, no. Not in here, Jamie. There's no movement either, is there.
We're on the ground, then.
Yes, I expect so. Ouch!
What's the matter? Well, don't keep me in suspense, what's happened?

Dialogue.Stage Direction: The Doctor pulls out a paper bag out of his pocket.

Dialogue.Line: Have a lemon sherbet. It'll quench your thirst.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: The Doctor goes to examine the door of the compartment.

Dialogue.Line: Doctor, the warning mechanism obviously thought there was something wrong out here, but what? I mean, everything's so, well, dead, isn't it?
Jamie.
What?
Look. It's a track.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: There are marks on the floor leading under the door.

Dialogue.Line: Why, that's oil. It must be some sort of machine. It's recent, too.
Well, I wonder what that would (Jamie presses a button and the door opens.)
I just. Oh.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: It is an empty corridor. They follow the track past two other doorways before reaching a blank metal shutter at the far end. There are controls and a monitor screen in the wall nearby.

Dialogue.Line: Shall we open the door?
No. No, there may be something on the other side. Here.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: The Doctor looks at the monitor controls and flicks a switch.

Dialogue.Line: Here we are.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: The image of a shadow-filled control room appears on the screen. It is filled with banks of computers and control panels, but there are no people visible. There is a small coffin-shaped pod next to an airlock, with a large metal crate on the other side.

Dialogue.Line: Looks safe enough.
Yes. What caused the defence mechanism of the Tardis to register danger then? And where's the crew? And what's this track? There's plenty of air in there. Let's try and get in.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: The door won't open.

Dialogue.Line: Oh. I'll look up here then.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: Jamie goes back to the first of the two doors and opens it. There's nothing interesting inside so he closes it and goes to the other one.

Dialogue.Line: Stores in that one.
It's living quarters here.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: The door closes behind them. There is a bunk bed and a dispensing machine, table and two chairs.

Dialogue.Line: Ah. Water!

Dialogue.Stage Direction: Meanwhile, in the control room, a squat, squared-off robot comes out of the shadow. It has two short stubby arms and protruding antennae, and illuminated detectors instead of a face. It communicates electronically with the rocket's systems. The door opens and the robot looks out. It sees nothing and the door closes again.

Dialogue.Line: I'd have thought a rocket this size would have carried more than two people.
Yes, Jamie, it does. It carries four. Two on duty and two resting.
Oh, the Tardis must have gone mad, then. I mean, there's nothing on board here, so there's no danger.
Isn't there?

Dialogue.Stage Direction: The Doctor looks through a porthole.

Dialogue.Line: We're just drifting, Jamie. Drifting aimlessly in space. Perhaps that's what the Tardis was trying to warn us about.
What's it matter?
Matter? We're just a piece of space flotsam, don't you realise that?
Well all right, stick your rod dimen
Time vector generator.
Aye, stick it back in, and we'll float off somewhere else.
No, it's not as simple as that, Jamie. The fluid, hmm? We need mercury to refill it, don't we.
Well there must be some on board here, surely?
Yes, I hope so.
Well there's got to be.
What's happened to the crew? They haven't just gone out for a little constitutional, you know.
Well, we won't find that out till we look inside that control room, will we?

Dialogue.Stage Direction: In the control room, a three-handed clock is running. The numeric display above reads 10,025 and falling.
The Doctor and Jamie have searched the ship.

Dialogue.Line: Well, I've searched my side. There's not a drop of mercury anywhere.
Me, too. No, the only place we haven't searched is that control room.
Well, we'll have a breather, and then we'll try in there.
And perhaps we'll find some food in that machine as well.
I can give you another lemon drop.
Something a bit more substantial, please.
What do you fancy?
Well right now I'd like a nice plate of roast beef with all the trimmings.
I'll see what I can do.
Eh? Ah now Doctor, where are you going to find a plate of roast beef on this place?

Dialogue.Stage Direction: The Doctor works the dispensing machine controls.

Dialogue.Line: What are you doing?
Roast beef, you said?
Well, yes.
What vegetables?
Potatoes
Potatoes.
And cabbage.
And cabbage. What about a drop of fruit salad?
Fruit salad, yes.
And I'll have some pork, potatoes and carrots. And, I'll have a drop of ice-cream.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: Two paper plates appear, with white cubes on them.

Dialogue.Line: There we are. what about the gravy?
I don't think so.
Gravy.
Am I supposed to eat this?
Yes, of course. It'll be delicious.
I've heard of a square meal, but this is ridiculous.
Sit down and eat up.
Doctor, what do you think Victoria's doing now?
Now? Time is relative, Jamie. If I knew when 'now' was, I might be able to hazard a guess.
You know what I mean.
Well, she's decided to stay in a good historical period. Very few wars, great prosperity. She'll be happy enough. This is very filling, isn't it?
Aye. Well, what do we do now?
Well, when we've digested our dinner we'll have another try to get into the control room.
Oh well, while you do that, I'm going to have a wee lie down.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: Jamie stretches out on the bunk.

Dialogue.Line: Tell me, though. What do you think happened to the crew?

I don't know, Jamie. I wish I did. I suppose they've been overtaken by some disaster or other. Perhaps we'll find out when we get into the control room. (The control room door opens and the little robot comes out and goes to the open door of the motor section. It is quite slow, and is constantly taking readings of its surroundings. The Doctor is using his pocket telescope to look out of the porthole.)
Well, at least we don't seem to be in any immediate danger, Jamie. But I would like to know

Dialogue.Stage Direction: Jamie is fast asleep.

The servo-robot has reached the Tardis. In the control room, the countdown reads 1,000. A light flashes on the robot's casing. It goes into the corridor and laser-welds the motor section door shut, then returns to the control room. After listening at the cabin door, the Doctor opens it and looks into the corridor. He sees a fresh set of oily tracks on the floor and follows them to the control room door. There he turns on the wall monitor, but it is full of static. Inside, the robot connects itself to a computer bank and the rocket begins to turn. The Doctor is thrown against a wall by the movement. Jamie is tipped from the bunk, and goes to find the Doctor.

Dialogue.Line: Doctor, what's happening?
I hit my head. Oh!
We're moving. The rocket's moving.
Yes, I know. There's someone in the control room.
Let's have a look.
No, no, Jamie. We've got to get back to the Tardis. It's the only safe place.
Doctor, the mercury stuff.
Never mind that.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: Jamie helps the groggy Doctor stand up and go to the motor section door.

Dialogue.Line: It won't open. Doctor, someone's sealed the door.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: The Doctor collapses. Jamie helps him up and into the cabin.

Dialogue.Line: Lock it, Jamie. Lock it.
Easy. Doctor, are you all right? Doctor?

Dialogue.Stage Direction: The Doctor has collapses onto the bunk.

Dialogue.Character: (In the control room, the robot disconnects from the computer and goes to the pod by the airlock. They exchange electronic signals then the pod opens to reveal a row of small white spheres. The inner and outer airlock doors open and the room depressurises. The countdown has reached Zero. The spheres float out through the airlock into space. The airlock closes and the robot repressurises the control room, then goes to a large monitor screen which now shows a large space station. Its top section is flattened, like a large wheel, with a complicated lattice of rocket motors and antennae below. The robot reconnects to the computer and the rocket stops.) JAMIE
Dialogue.Line: Doctor, there's a great big silver thing out here. DOCTOR: Into the Tardis. I've got to get him to safety.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: Jamie is looking out of the porthole as the Doctor crawls into the corridor, takes a cap off one end of the time vector generator and points it at the sealed motor section door. A beam vapourises the seal. When he has finished, the Doctor puts the cap back on the TVG and puts the device in his pocket. Before he can open the door, he is aware of the robot right behind him.

Dialogue.Line: Doctor, you must see this.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: Jamie looks out of the cabin to see the robot. He grabs the metallic blanket from the bunk and throws it over the machine, which skitters away, blind.

Dialogue.Line: Back to the cabin, quick!
Easy. Easy now.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: Outside, the robot blows the blanket off with a jet of air and heads for the cabin.

Dialogue.Line: Jamie, take this. It's a gun. Like a torch. You have to be careful.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: He gives Jamie the TVG as the robot's laser begins to burn through the cabin door. Carefully, Jamie unscrews the tip of the rod and aims it at the door. The beam hits the robot, sending it flying down to the door of the motor section where it explodes.

Dialogue.Line: Oh. We're all right for the time being. But listen, you. Mo more gallivanting about till I say so, all right? Doctor? Doctor?

Dialogue.Stage Direction: The Doctor is unconscious.

Dialogue.Line: On Red band emergency frequency, come in, please. Come in, please. Station Three to Silver Carrier, Station Three to Silver Carrier. On Red band emergency frequency, come in please.
All ready, Leo?
Yes, sir. It's locked on now.
That's it. Don't get much fun, do we? Better make the most of it.
Make a change from blasting meteorites, wouldn't it?
Jarvis?
Hold it a minute. Tanya, can we take a visual recording of it?
Yes sir, can do.
Still no movement or radio ,signals sir.
Put up the anti-magnetic shield, Leo, when I give the word.
Right.
Still going to plan, sir.
Good, I'll do an announcement about reverberations.
Before you do that, Jarvis, can I have a word? It's important.
More bogeys.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: Corwyn and Bennett move away.

Dialogue.Line: All systems on green. Stand by.
Green. Stand by.
I don't know what you grinning about.
Neither do I.
It isn't funny, Leo. The Controller's like a kid with a new toy.
Oh, don't tell me you're going to be a old stick in the mud, too?
If you are referring to Doctor Corwyn, she is known. She is no stick in the mud. She's perfectly right to be cautious.
Come on, Tanya. It's off course about eighty million miles. I mean, there can't possibly be anyone alive on the thing.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: On the Silver Carrier, Jamie is trying to shine a signal light out of the cabin porthole. He pulls the light to far and the cable comes out, putting the room into darkness. He sees a small glow by the Doctor. It is the Time Vector Generator. Jamie holds it up to the porthole.

Dialogue.Line: Yes, I know all that, Jarvis, but we still can't be absolutely certain.
Gemma, one thing that I beg of you. Don't subject me to psychoanalysis. You think I'm having a whale of a time, don't you? All kids again. Bang, bang, blow up the balloon. You're wrong, you know.
Am I?
Say what you like, the Silver Carrier is a menace to the Wheel. Now surely you can see that?
If you equate menace with automatic power drive, I don't.
What else?
You want me to believe some emergency happened on the Silver Carrier. The pilot switched to automatic and then tragedy.
Right.
And all the crew died?
Right again.
Where was the Carrier bound for, Jarvis?
Servicing Station Five. I told you.
Then isn't it be reasonable to assume that the automatic would have taken it to Station Five?
Yes, that's good reasoning. But you're forgetting the emergency. That could have damaged the control sensors. In fact, it must have done, which is why the rocket is so far off course.
Assumption again, guesswork. It would be so easy to check.
We can't risk that rocket turning in on us. Don't you see? It'd blast a hole right through us!

Dialogue.Stage Direction: Jamie takes the cap off the TVG.
The Radio operator rips his headphones off in pain.

Dialogue.Line: What the matter?
Noise! Fantastic noise through my headphones.
Leo! The approach indicators are all at red!
What's causing it? Green system's gone crazy. Tanya, get Doctor Corwyn. Check emergency system yellow.
Emergency yellow, negative.
Transfer internal communications to my cell.
Bill!
Yo!
Will you lie him down there?
Hey, hey, hey, you don't want to do that again.
Hey, listen!

Dialogue.Stage Direction: The interference can be heard coming through the headsets.

Dialogue.Line: Don't argue with me, Gemma. The decision is mine! This station and the people on it are my responsibility.
Rudkin's hurt!
What happened?
Colossal static pulses swamping the detectors.
It's the rocket. I knew it was a menace. (Jamie uses the cap of the TVG to create a pulsed signal.)

Dialogue.Stage Direction: Bennett, Corwyn and Lernov enter.

Dialogue.Line: All right, Tanya, get back to the complex. See if you can pin this static down.
Vallance, Casali, here. Well?
It's bad.
Can we move him?
Yes.
Right. You two, take him to the Medical Bay.
Gently with him, now.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: Rudkin is carried out.

Dialogue.Line: Your attention. That rocket has given us enough trouble. Bill, knock it out.
Right, sir.
Controller!
Yes, what is it?
The static. There's a signal on it.
There can't be.
You're right, Tanya. Get me a fix on that.
If I can. It's not any code that I've ever heard before but there's definitely a repetitive order to it.
It's no good using radio or radar. We will have to use millimicron waves.
You think it's coming from the rocket?
Just want to make sure that it's not coming from anywhere else.
The rocket. It is!
You're sure?
Certain. I was fixed on it anyway. There's no doubt.
Then somebody is on board. Phil!
Sir.
I want two men to cross over. Organise it, will you?
Right sir.
Eighty million miles off course. If they're alive on board that craft, they must be in a pretty bad way.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: After a little while, Jamie stops signalling and checks on the Doctor. He is still unconscious, so he returns to the porthole to see a space-suited figure looking in. The newcomer gestures towards the front of the rocket. Jamie goes to the control room but the door is locked. Two men have already entered through the airlock. They repressurise the control room and the door opens.

Dialogue.Line: Quick, I've somebody injured in here.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: Laleham, an American, has taken over as radio operator.

Dialogue.Line: Voyager five, call sign K-1 2 10-Q. Confirm please, Station 3.
Receiving you, Station 3. Hello, hello?
Light to medium meteorite storm across your planned route between thirteen hundred fourteen hundred hours. Coordinates: A alpha 2710 point 4, B beta 4 point 7. Do you receive Voyager Five?
Yes, thank you for the information, Station 3.
We have computed an alternative route for you, Voyager Five. Stand by for instructions.
Computer standing by now.
How are the guests?
Doctor Corwyn's examining the older one now. They're both slightly in shock anyway.
What's the story?
I don't know. Quite a mystery, isn't it.
Jarvis won't like that. What that on green system three, Chang?
(Oriental) Very odd, sir. Been getting one or two funny signs here and there all the time. Soon as you check them out they vanish.
Put them in the log, okay?
Yes, sir. It as if a number of magnets were touching the outer skin of the wheel and then letting go. Localised field effects, that's all.
All detector fields are checked out, sir. Can't be anything serious.
Well, keep a log and let me know.
Right, sir.
More mysteries.
I know.
Something else worrying you, Tanya?
What about those sudden drops in air pressure levels? They were small enough and soon adjust themselves but I didn't like it.
How small?
Only a few millimetres. One degree, sometimes one and a half.
Hmm. Some fault in the air supply unit, or the pumps.
In so many different parts of the Wheel?
Did you tell Jarvis?
Of course. He bit my head off.
And have you told Gemma Corwyn yet?
No, she was busy with the new arrivals. I didn't like to disturb her.
Well, if I were you Tanya, I start a check on the whole air supply unit.
That's what I thought. Leo?
Hmm?
None of these things. Your system showing temporary faults, the air pressure levels. Well, they all started with the rocket, didn't they?
What, you think there are little green men on board, do you?
Well, the two they bought back wasn't exactly normal, were they?
Well, I tell you what, hey? If you get scared, I'll let you hold my hand. Okay?
I'm serious.
So am I.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: More of the spheres from the rocket are getting through the outer hull of the wheel.
Jamie is baring his chest for a check-up.

Dialogue.Line: Breathe in again. Out. In again please. Out. Now, I want you to take a deep breath and exhale as slowly as you can. Good. You can dress now.
How about the Doctor?
Concussion, certainly. I am waiting for the X-Rays to see if there's any fracture. What were you both up to?
Hey?
Fancy dress or something? Your clothes.
Look, have you ever thought what you look like walking down the street in those things. People would think you were a wee bit strange as well.
I dare say. But I don't understand the analogy. We're both in space. It's you and your friend who aren't conforming to custom.
How about the medical? Do I pass?
You'll do. If it's any comfort to you, you are in fine physical shape. Can you give me your full name please? JAMIE: James Robert McCrimmon. Jamie.
Thank you. And your friend?
Er, the Doctor.
I can't put that down.
Er. John Smith.
Really?
Aye.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: Corwyn sees that her medical equipment was manufactured by John Smith and Associates.

Dialogue.Line: Doctor John Smith.
They must be a lot of them about.
I dare say. You were passengers aboard the Silver Carrier, were you?
Er, do you think that I could have a drink of water, please?
What happened to the crew?
I don't know.
Could you go further than that?
Well, I was ill in the cabin, you see. A terrible fever. Raving for days. Well, when I came to, the door was closed against us, the Doctor was hurt and your people came.
All the communicating doors were closed against you?
Aye.
And your friend didn't tell you what happened?
No.
All right, Jamie, that'll do for the present. The Controller will want to have a chat with you. We'll have to get you home somehow.
Aye, that'll be the day. Oh, of course.
There should be another ship passing through in a week or two.
Oh, can I go now?
You didn't drink your water.
No, well, that's all right.
Wait a moment.
What?
Would you like to see over the Wheel? I could arrange it for you, if you like.
Oh, yes. I mean, there's nothing else to do.
Well, if you go along the corridor you'll see a door marked Parapsychology library.
Para what?
It's on the other side of the Wheel complex, about eight sections on. I'll tell Zoe to show you round.
Zoe?
She's our. Well, the best way to describe her would be to call her our librarian.
Zoe, you say?
That's right.
Oh, you will tell me what happens to the Doctor.
Yes, of course.
Thank you.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: Jamie leaves. Corwyn turns on a monitor.

Dialogue.Line: Parapsychology library, Doctor Corwyn calling.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: A young dark-haired girl answers.

Dialogue.Line: Parapsychology library. What reference do you require, Doctor Corwyn?
No reference, thank you, Zoe. I need your help in another way. ZOE [on monitor]: Oh?
One of the people retrieved from the rogue spaceship is coming to your section. I'd like you to show him over the Wheel and observe him. ZOE [on monitor]: Observe him?
Discreetly, of course. ZOE [on monitor]: Do you want these observations recorded?
Yes, please. ZOE [on monitor]: Hmm, should be interesting. Any facts known?
Yes. He is a nice lad. His name's Ja ZOE [on monitor]: Just a minute. Sorry, I was halfway through a RNA analysis when you came on. Right.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: Jamie is walking along the corridor looking for a long and complex word on a door. He finds one and pushes the door open
It is dominated by a large circular desk with Zoe is seated in the middle.

Dialogue.Line: With the exception of the Hercules cluster. Confirmation of the information received that one of the stars in the Messier 13 group is entering a nova phase. This will be a repetition of the phenomenon observed in the Perseus cluster last week. Information of the gamma radiation level is available.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: Zoe turns off the recorder.

Dialogue.Line: Sorry. You must be (laughs)
What are you laughing at?
Your clothes. You're wearing female garments.
Female? Look, I'll have you know this is a kilt. Have you not seen it before?
Kilt? Kilt. A barbaric form of garment as worn by a kiltie! Are you of Scandinavian origin? Danish?
No, I am not. I am a true bred Scot and I'll just thank you to
Oh, a Scot. Scotland, of course. Pre-century history isn't my field, you see.
Aye, maybe not, but just you watch your lip or I'll put you across my knee and larrup you.
Oh, this is going to be fun. I shall learn a lot from you. Come on, James Robert McCrimmon. Do you know anything about interstellar flora?
Eh?

Dialogue.Stage Direction: They meet Bill Duggan.

Dialogue.Line: And this is my little kingdom. Hey, how do you like the Greenhouse?
Do you collect these?

No, they're floating seeds. The only place they flourish is down here in the power room. Of course, the old man kicked up a mad dust storm at first, but Doc Corwyn said it was good psychology or something. Anyway, I just like flowers. Hey, that one comes all the way from Venus. Can you imagine that? All those millions of miles away.
24,564,000 miles at perihelion and 161,350,000 miles at aphelion.
Oh, I was dying to know that.
And this is the capacitator bank for the x-ray lasers.
The what?
Oh, it controls the laser gun. Without it the gun's useless.
What do you need a gun for up in space anyway?
Self-defence. We can blot out any attacker up to ten thousand miles in any one direction. Good eh?
Reassuring.
Yeah, and they're the anti-magnetic field generators. They can vend off even a medium-sized meteorite up to fifty miles.
You know, Bill, the Doctor'll love all this.
This Doctor friend of yours. Is he a scientist?
He is in a way, I suppose, yes.
What's his specialty?
He's what?
Well, is he a physicist, biochemist, astronomer, biometrician
Yes, he is.
Well, he certainly sounds a interesting character, this Doctor friend of yours. When is he going to be up and about?
If he is just suffering from concussion, not too long.
Oh, it doesn't tell me much. I want facts.
I don't blame you.
We're landed with a couple of strays. Panic, mysteries from the crew. The routine's getting shoddy and I don't like it.
What panics?
Oh, nothing, nothing. I'll tell you if it gets serious. People are just edgy. Out in space, human beings have got to rely on routines, ordinariness. Confuse them and you got trouble.
Yes.
I'm used to emergencies. Trained in them. But these things? I don't know
What you call mysteries?
Exactly, exactly. I don't want to know, Gemma. I don't want to know. Well, you see.
You'd better hear my preliminary report on the boy.
Yes, go ahead.
He's lying. Not completely and apparently reluctantly. He's very fit both mentally and physically, nice constructive personality. His blood pressure suggests he's not been in space very long.
Lies about what?
He said he had fever aboard the Silver Carrier. He hadn't. His gamma globulins are normal.
Oh? Why should he lie about that?
I asked him what happened to the crew. Fever was his excuse for not knowing. And then again he lied. At least, I almost sure he lied about his friend's name. John Smith, he called him.
Well, they do exist, you know.
Yes, he was looking at that for long enough. Coincidence possibly. Somehow I doubt it. And then, what's the most precious thing in deep space, Jarvis?
Air, water, take your pick.

Exactly. In space training even for one journey travellers. He asked me for a drink of water and then he left it. He might have been on Earth. That boy's has no space travel training, Jarvis. He's probably a stowaway, or he may be an agent.
Sabotage?
Plenty of people on Earth think we should suspend the space programme. Some of them have forced their opinions already.
Do you think these two could have stowed away somehow, even disposed of the crew of the Silver Carrier, pretended to drift here helplessly, we take them in and they start breaking things up?
I don't go that far.
Well of course, it's fits! Everything fits!
I only suggested it as a possibility, Jarvis. There are others.
We'll talk about those later. This could be serious.
Jarvis, wait. I
And this is the Operations and Communications room.
What does this Wheel thing do up here anyway?

Well, it has varied functions, but mainly it's a radio-visual relay for Earth, a half-way house for deep space ships, a space research station, stellar early warning station for all types of space phenomena and
Aye, well, ask a silly question.
Not there. That's the Controller's chair.
Hey, you're in for quite a treat.
I am?
The old man's going ahead then?
Too right he is.
I thought Gemma talked him out of it.
No, only because she thought there might still be somebody on board. Just as well for you.
I'm sorry, I lost you in the first part.
The Controller, Jarvis Bennett, wanted to destroy the rocket.
And then we got your message.
Only minutes in it too. The laser was all primed and ready to blast.
Has Jarvis given the go-ahead?
Yes, I've run a new co-ordinate fix. Everything's programmed and ready. All we need now is the final signal.
Oh, you're not going to blow up the rocket, then?
Well, it might hit us, so to be on the safe side we blast it out of existence.
Jarvis asked me to make a visual recording of it. I'd better re- position. Zoe, help me do a quick mental calculation, would you? You're quicker than me.
It'll be great to see this at leisure. It should be quite an explosion.
Right, Zoe? Lineal reading is 198.42 metres at 23 degrees latitude. 190.03 metres. 24 degree latitude.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: Jamie leaves quietly and goes back to the power room. There he finds the x-ray laser's capacitator bank, but doesn't notice some small twisted pieces of metal on the floor. Jamie searches a shelf of bottles and canisters.

Dialogue.Line: But he was definitely here?
Yes, he just vanished.
Bill, any ideas?
No, sir. He was here with us. We were showing him around.
Where?
Well, the power house
The power house.
Yes, sir.
Look, Bill, not a word to the others. Just follow me in a moment or two. Zoe, not a word.
Right, sir.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: Bennett leaves.

Dialogue.Line: Don't look at me, I don't know what's going on.
Problems?
I don't know.
It's all in the mind, dear, it's all in the mind. I'll see you.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: Duggan leaves.

Dialogue.Line: What was the Controller talking to Bill Duggan about, Zoe?
Nothing important. At least I don't think so. I don't know. Does it matter? (Zoe leaves.)
Hey, what's all the whispering about?
I wish I knew. Leo, did I ever tell you about my nose?
Your nose?
Yes. It's like a barometer. It never lets me down.
Oh.
I smell trouble.
Can you pin point it?
Hmm. It's something to do with that rocket out there. There's something sinister about it.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: Silver Carrier is on the monitor.

Dialogue.Line: My nose never lets me down.
Well, don't overwork it, eh? I mean, it's rather pretty. Too much exercise might damage its shape.
If something happens, don't say I didn't warn you. That's rocket dangerous.
Nah, not for long. As soon as Jarvis gives the word, the laser'll blast it out of existence.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: Jamie spots a spray labelled Quick-set plastic on a shelf. He takes it to the capacitator, pulls a section out and sprays the stuff on it before pushing it back. The machine slows down. Then he is grabbed before he can do it to another piece of the machine.

Dialogue.Line: Red-handed.
No, wait, let me explain
What do you think you're doing, you fool!
Oh, he's no fool, are you. You're a saboteur!
No, I'm not! I'm
Shut up!

Dialogue.Stage Direction: Duggan tries to remove the plastic with another spray.

Dialogue.Line: It's no good. He's wrecked it.
Completely?
Yeah.
Watch him.
All right. I won't give you any trouble.
Too right, you won't!

Dialogue.Stage Direction: Bennett makes a broadcast.

Dialogue.Line: Now hear this. This is the Controller.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: Zoe and Corwyn listen.

Dialogue.Line: All men on Security duty to issue themselves with sidearms at once. Easy Yellow security plan to be put into effect immediately. Two off- duty men, security
Section, report to the power room on the double!
Easy Yellow? Well now what's the sudden panic?
I told you Bill and the Controller were up to something.
I'd better log out the blasters. Keep a eye on the Hercules cluster, will you? Zoe thinks one of the stars in Messier 13 is about to enter the nova state.
That's all we need! A star blowing into a thousand pieces. I told you my nose never lets me down.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: Two fully 'grown' Cybermen have hatched from those spheres. They get instructions from a strange cybernetic creature via the monitors.

Dialogue.Line: Report. CYBERMAN 1: Phase one complete. PLANNER [on monitor]: Cybermats are launched. CYBERMAN 1: Phase two complete. PLANNER [on monitor]: You are undetected on the rocket? CYBERMAN 1: Phase three ready. PLANNER [on monitor]: Report again after phase three.
All sections, Easy Yellow alert.
You'd better check your theory, Zoe.
Oh, I'm right. Hercules 208 in Messier 13 is definitely on the blink. I can tell you what the radiation affect will be on Earth, if you like.
Not now.
I suppose you're going to see the fun, whatever it is.
Somehow, I don't think this is fun.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: Two guards are holding Jamie as Duggan checks the capacitator.

Dialogue.Line: Yeah, I see.
Well?
Yeah.
Well?
You've done a good job, boy.
What's the exact damage?
Serious, sir. All of the primary relay contacts are fused shut. This whole unit'll have to be stripped down.
How long?
Well, that depends on how much plastic he used and how far down it went.
How long?
I honestly don't know, Chief.
Well surely you can give me some idea? Without the laser beams, we're virtually helpless.
All right, well, let's assume the worst, that the laser's absolutely finished. I mean, this charged storage part of it. A replacement could take a week.
A week?

Dialogue.Stage Direction: Corwyn enters.

Dialogue.Line: What's the trouble, Jarvis?
This young idiot has ruined the laser. Poured quick-seal plastic right into the relay lines of the booster mirrors!
Why?
Sabotage!
No.
What are you? One of these pull back to Earth maniacs? Where are your friends, eh? Out there in deep space just waiting to come in and attack us when you put our laser out of action?
Och, you're talking rubbish!
You can't deny anything, boy. We saw you.
I'm not denying it.
Is the laser really out of action, Jarvis?
Yes, it is.
Zoe's calculated a new star going nova. We haven't checked with radar yet but she's usually right.
How bad?
The radiation flux will swing the Perseus shower right in on us. With the laser we could at least knock some of them out.
Hey, I'd better get started.
We must confirm Zoe's figures with the radar computers. Come on, bring him.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: Duggan makes a broadcast as Bennett, Corwyn, Jamie and his guards leave.

Dialogue.Line: All hands to the power room. Immediate and urgent. All hands to the power room. Oh, what a mess.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: A Cybermat enters.

Dialogue.Line: Well, I'll be. Hey. Hey, hang on. Hang on, I'm not going to hurt you. Well, where did you spring from? You're metal. Hey, you're a strange little creature, aren't you? Some form of space bug?

Dialogue.Stage Direction: There are footsteps outside. Duggan picks up the Cybermat and puts it in a cupboard.

Dialogue.Line: Well, Billy, we'd better hide you, Billy Bug, or they'll think that I've gone bonkers.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: Two men enter.

Dialogue.Line: Ah. Lets get started right away, shall we?
Confirm Zoe's figures on radar computers two and five. You didn't let yourself know what you're letting yourself in for, did you? Have you ever been in a sky station when a meteorite hits?
Look, I'm sorry.
Why did you do it?
Well, they said that you were going to blow up the rocket.
So?
Why not?
Well, I couldn't let you, that's all.
Why? Why?
Because the Doctor told me to protect it.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: The Doctor is sitting up against an angled bed. There's a padded silver chair in the corner and monitoring equipment nearby.

Dialogue.Line: Well that's marvellous, isn't it? The Doctor told me to protect it. You don't give a reason, just leave me to get you out of trouble.
Well, I had to stop them destroying the rocket, didn't I?
Oh, I suppose so.
Of course I did. I mean, what about the Tardis? A fine thing if they'd blown that to pieces.
I was just beginning to enjoy this little rest.
Anyway, what are you going to tell them?
I don't know. Jamie, what exactly did happen on the rocket? Well don't look at me like that.
You don't remember?
It's a bit hazy.
Well, I found you lying in the corridor near that locked control room. Something had just shaken up the rocket and tumbled me out of bed and, well, whatever it was must have made you stumble as well.
I suppose I hit my head.
You honestly can't remember?
No, but it's there. It's there at the back of my mind.
Well, what about the machine then? The one that was going to attack you. Now surely you remember that?
Machine? No. But there's something. Some warning, some menace. **[Rocket control room]**.
Report progress. CYBERMAN 1: All phases proceeding as planned. PLANNER [on monitor]: Prepare phase four.
Yes. Yes, it's all happening in the Hercules cluster okay.
I told you. The same thing happened in the Perseus cluster a week ago.
Except we had the laser then. We could deflect the meteorites.
Picture. There it is. And beginning to emit hard gamma already.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: The dots are on the radar screen.

Dialogue.Line: It's bigger than the Perseus one, Rico.
It's four magnitudes up. Well, I see if I can get some further information for you.
I'd better give the bad news to the Controller.
Leo, what we going to do if Bill can't repair the laser in time?
Well, we've got the convolute force field.
The neutron barriers won't help us. A star of this magnitude when it goes nova, deflects meteorites with a mass of two hundred tons each.
Two hundred
At least.
Aren't you ever wrong?
Rarely.
No, it's all a problem in solid geometry to you, isn't it. Don't you care what happens here?
Well, of course. I'm only telling you what's going to happen.
Just like a robot. Fact, calculations.
Leo!
Proper little brainchild. All brain and no heart!

Dialogue.Stage Direction: The plasticised unit is being removed.

Dialogue.Line: Gently now, gently. Keep it upright. Good, good. Fine, get maintenance started on that right away, will you?

Dialogue.Stage Direction: The technicians leave. Duggan spots the Cybermat by the cupboard.

Dialogue.Line: Hello Billy-bug. You should had stay where I

Dialogue.Stage Direction: He picks up a piece of debris by a box labelled Bernalium.

Dialogue.Line: Hey, did you do this? (He opens the cupboard and the Cybermat scurries away.)
What have you done?

Dialogue.Stage Direction: Rudkin enters

Dialogue.Line: What's the matter?
What? Oh, nothing. How's it going?
Okay now. Doctor Corwyn's taken me off communications.
Good. Good.
The Controller asked me to come and see how you were getting along.
Ohm you can tell him we're making good time. Er, hey, come on, will you do something for me?
Yes?
Go into to Spares and ask them to check their Bernalium stock, will you?
Right.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: Rudkin leaves. Duggan checks the boxes in the cupboard.

Dialogue.Line: Well, that's all right, anyway. I'll murder that little pest.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: Duggan goes to work on the laser and two Cybermats come out from the broken box.
Corwyn is using the John Smith device to check the Doctor.

Dialogue.Line: You and your friend are healthy specimens, aren't you.
Oh, we keep fit one way and another. I suppose all this mean I've got to get up.
No, I'm afraid not just yet.
Oh good.
Does your head ache?
Well, it did, but it's better now.
Any loss of memory?
Well, just a little.
Does it make you anxious?
I think you'll find my psyche in very good order.

Probably, but don't strain to remember. Concussion can bring about temporary lapses in memory. There is quite a lot we don't know about the memory bank yet, you know. Good. I suppose the part that you can't remember is why you told Jamie to protect the rocket.
Oh yes, I can, perfectly. We're not saboteurs, you know.
Probably not.
The last thing we want to do is to interfere with what you're doing here, or put you in any danger. You saved our lives on that rocket and we're very grateful.
But you have interfered. We are in the path of a very serious meteorite storm, the second we've been threatened with in a week. Only we have no defence against this new one.
But I tell you, I didn't know about the meteorites.
I hope not.
I don't even know what they are.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: Zoe enters.

Dialogue.Line: Is it all right? The guard said you are here.
Guard?
We can't let you roam about wherever you want to.
Aye, we're under arrest.
Oh, no.
How did you pilot the rocket, Doctor?
I don't think we've met, have we?
Zoe, Doctor John Smith, isn't it?
John. (nudging the Doctor) John.
Oh. Oh, yes. And what do you do here, Zoe?
I'm an astrophysicist. Pure mathematics major.
With honours.
Oh, I am impressed.
We use Zoe as our second opinion.
You didn't answer my question.
What question?
You know, I'm surprised you didn't know the answer. Now don't tell me there's something you can't work out.

How did you pilot the rocket ship? You see, I've calculated its original course. It was a service and supply station for number five station, overdue and presumed lost nine weeks ago. Well, the rocket couldn't drift eighty seven million miles off course.
So what's your theory?

Well, there's a record of the last contract with the Silver Carrier rocket. It had seven million miles to touchdown and enough fuel for twenty million. Well, it couldn't have drifted here off course in the time involved. It must have been driven and piloted.
Oh, a right wee space detective.
There's only one solution. That rocket was re-fuelled in space. Provided with at least with another twelve fuel rods.
Well, it's an interesting theory.
Oh, it isn't a theory. You can't disprove the facts. It's pure logic.
Logic, my dear Zoe, merely enables one to be wrong with authority. Supposing there was a faulty automatic pilot.
To drive a rocket eighty seven million miles on fuel for twenty million?
Well, it's a possibility.
That rocket was driven here somehow. I know it was.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: On the Silver Carrier, things are moving along.

Dialogue.Line: We have ionised a star. Perseid meteorites will strike the Wheel. CYBERMAN 2: Phrase three is in operation. PLANNER [on monitor]: The Cybermats will consume Bernalium. Without Bernalium the Wheel cannot deflect the meteorites. CYBERMAN 1: They will discover Bernalium on board this rocket-ship. CYBERMAN 2: Phrase four is ready. PLANNER [on monitor]: Remove telemeter control from Cybermats. (Transmission ends. Cyberman 1 zaps the clock face and the third hand starts whizzing around as the ammeter needle maxes out, switches flick and lights blink. On the Wheel, the Cybermat's eyes flash.)
Let me get this right, Bill. You say the Bernalium is
Gemma, it's useless. All of it.
What about the reserve?

Yeah. I had a check made of the stock but then I remembered I'm holding most of it over in the Power room. Well, you know how much we rely on those Bernalium rods. I mean, they're the only ones that stand up inside the X-ray laser.
I'm far more interested in these creatures of yours.
Oh, there's only one of them. At least, that's all I've found.
Did anyone else see it?
No.
Did you tell anybody else about it?
Oh, you're joking. Look, they think I'm a nut anyway for messing about with space flora. How do you think they're going to react if I tell them I found a space bug.
What's it like?
Oh, it's smallish, about so big. Made of metal or some light tensile material.
And you say that it eat metal?
No, not exactly. It's sort of draws the life out of it, you know. Corrodes it. You should see what it's done to the Bernalium stock.
But how did this space bug get into the Wheel in the first place?
You can search me, I just found it. It could have gone through one of the loading bays or one of the airlocks.
Yes, I suppose that's possible.
What's the matter? You think I am a nut too, do you?
No, but I want to see this creature for myself, Bill.
All right. Come on, I'll introduce you to Billy Boy.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: Rudkin enters. He sees the Cybermats rooting around the Bernalium boxes, and grabs a wrench from a shelf. The Cybermats head for him then their eyes light up. Rudkin screams and drops the wrench, clutching his wrist. Two more Cybermats appear, surrounding him. Rudkin grabs the Quick drying plastic spray and covers one Cybermat with it. Its friends zap him again and he drops the spray, both hands now useless. He screams as they move in again. Corwyn and Duggan hear him in the corridor and run to help.
The screams are heard in the rest room. Jamie and Zoe run to the door and are stopped by the guard.

Dialogue.Line: You can't come out.
What was that scream?
I don't know. It sounded as if all the devils in hell was hounding someone, but you still can't come out.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: Duggan and Corwyn enter to find Rudkin amongst the remains of plants and shelving.

Dialogue.Line: Is he dead?
Yes. I'll tell the Controller.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: Corwyn sees the plastic covered lump on the floor.

Dialogue.Line: What's that?

Dialogue.Stage Direction: The lump is on a tray and being examined by the Doctor. Jamie is prodding it with his sgian dubh.

Dialogue.Line: The Controller's mounted an immediate enquiry. I'm much more interested in this.
This was found by the body, was it?
Yes. I had to get one of the men to take a floor plate up. You just can't cut through hyperoxide. It's polymer strength is higher than chrome steel.
The Gordian knot couldn't be untied, either.
I don't know what that means.
Oh it means that there's er
It means there's always a solution.
Aye.
And the Bernalium is a write-off, is it?
Completely. We've got a few spares but not half enough. We'll have to get more up from Earth.
And the X-ray laser gun, the main armament of the Wheel, relies on Bernalium?
Do you think there's a connection?
It's a possibility, isn't it. Jamie, what do you think?
Me? Well, there can be a saboteur on board. Jarvis Bennett, de did say something about a group of people. Earth For Earth, something like that.
Well, there are such people. They do want to stop the space programme.
Aye, well, just supposing they planted a saboteur on board, waiting for the right moment. Along drifts the rocket and we're abroad. The saboteur thinks this is the right moment and strikes.
And murders?
Well, if he was caught messing about with the Bernalium stuff, he may had to kill.
Well, it's an interesting theory.
But it fits.
Hmm.. It doesn't fit this.
Which we can't cut inside.
Och, it's just a spare part or something. The dead man tried to defend himself, used the quick set plastic, it misfired and went over this bit of machinery.
Well, we can find out.
How?
With the X-ray machine.
Of course. Why didn't I think of that?
Aye, why didn't you?
Well, all I had to go on was the fact that hyperoxide is unbreakable. I just didn't think of X-rays.
Simple common sense works wonders sometimes, Zoe.
Well, at least you didn't think of X-rays. That would have been awful.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: Duggan is getting a dressing-down.

Dialogue.Line: You're under restriction. I'll have you back to Earth on the next ship that puts in. I want a written report on the whole affair, and I want it in my hands tomorrow morning, first thing. That's all.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: Duggan moves away.

Dialogue.Line: He's confined to quarters. Tanya, you'll have to take over some of Leo's operations.
Very well.
Now, Leo, I want that laser working as soon as possible. Get on to it at once.
Controller.
In a minute. Now, all of you. Let's get back to normal working conditions. Gemma, I want a word with you in my quarters. All right?
Laleham and Vallance are ready, sir. Waiting for a go-ahead.
Give it.
Yes, sir. Hello, travel party. You are free to embark now. We will operate air pass doors and emergency stand-bys.
Entering departure hatch for oxygen rating now. Standing by.
Yes, receiving you. Stand by for

Dialogue.Stage Direction: Bennett and Corwyn leave, and we pan over to the other side of the room.

Dialogue.Line: This is Voyager 8 standing by, station 3.
I'm sorry, Bill.
It's my own fault. I'm a fool.
You didn't do anything.
I should have told somebody. I know the old man doesn't believe me but there was a creature there.
We did search round, Bill. Your power house is in a heck of a mess. There wasn't a sign of anything.
I didn't dream it, did I? Oh, what's the use of talking. Rudkin's dead. I'd give anything to. Oh, what's the use of talking. (Duggan leaves.)
I thought you said you found some corroded metal in the Power room.
Yes. Gemma wanted me to keep quiet about it until she talked to Jarvis. You know, all this extra work means we won't be spending all too much spare time together.
I'll find someone else to keep me company. I'd hate it if you didn't have a sense of humour.

No, no, no! There's too much unexplained. Too many irrational phenomena. What's the matter with you people? I can't turn round without somebody dreaming up some odd little thing happening, some bit of emotionally- based fantasy!
Calm down, Jarvis.
Did you hear that fool, Duggan. Space rodent. The man's a wreck.
Jarvis, will you listen?
If it's sensible, yes.
I like to go through some facts.
All right. All right, I'm listening.

One, the rocket drifts near us. Two, drops in temperature, temporary, adjustment back to normal. Three, drops in air pressure, temporary, adjustment back to normal. Four, two meteorite storms of above average dimension, both within seven days. Five, two strangers bought to the Wheel. One of them sabotages our armaments.
Don't lump all those things together. I thought that you were going to be sensible.
They could be connected.
Oh, for heaven's sake, Gemma, don't you start. What are you going to do, make trouble?

We've got trouble, Jarvis. You're putting your head in the sand. Bill Duggan's apparitions, call them what you like, only started appearing after the rocket appeared, after the drops in air pressure. And Bernalium, the one thing vital to our defences, Bernalium is corroded just at the time when we're facing a big meteorite storm. I tell you that rocket is the basis of all our troubles.
Well don't you worry about that. I've got some men to go across and look it over. But mysteries? Please, Gemma, not you as well.
The X-rays are processed now. Can you turn out the light, Jamie?
Here we go. Now, let's see what we got. (The image projected on the wall clearly shows what is inside the plastic.)
What's that?
It's a Cybermat!
Aye.
The lights, Jamie, the lights. Cybermats.
That means the Cybermen must be here too.
Yes, and there is only one place where they can be. On that rocket!
And what's all that supposed to mean?
The Cybermen are threatening this Space Wheel.
Cybermen? Where'd you dream up a name like that.
The study of a system of control and communication in animals, and devices such as cybernetic machines.
What are you talking about?
Cybernetics.
I know all there is to know about Cybernetics. I don't need a lecture from you.
But Cybermen exist. You've got to believe me. You've got to!
On the evidence of one faked-up X-ray shot.
It's not faked-up. I took it myself, Controller.
Well, what are these Cybermen then?
They were once men, human beings like yourself, from the planet Mondas, but now they're more robot then man.
You mean half and half?
Oh no, more than that. Their entire bodies are mechanical and their brains have been treated neuro-surgically to remove all human emotions, all sense of pain. They're ruthless, inhuman killers!
You really expect me to believe that rubbish!
It's not rubbish! They'll kill anyone who stands in their path. You've got to believe me. You've just got to!
You will ferry us to the Wheel. Obey. Inside the Wheel you will help us.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: The two Cybermen climb into a large empty crate and lie down. Laleham and Vallance fit a false floor over them then fill the space with Bernalium fuel rods.

Dialogue.Line: But don't you understand? The Cybermen will get inside this space Wheel.
Nothing just comes in and out of this Wheel, What do you think this is, a jet heliport?
They already sent their Cybermats in to weaken you.
Look, listen to him. He's telling you the truth!
No, I'll tell you what he's doing. What too many people are trying to do. I don't know why, it must be space sickness. They're spreading fear, alarm, terror. You think I can't see it?
He's sincere, Jarvis. At least listen
How could anything get inside the Wheel, Gemma, How? How could it get through the airlock. Perhaps it'll float through the loading bay in full view of everybody.
It's still worth listening and taking precautions just in case there is some truth in all this.
Don't try and tell me my job, Gemma. I am still Controller of this Wheel and things will be run in my way. Any orders to the contrary can come from Earth Central. That's what.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: Bennett stops in mid-sentence and leaves.

Dialogue.Line: Oh, dear. How do you convince a man like that?
That X-ray. I think Bill Duggan should see it. Go and find him, will you Zoe?
Isn't he confined to his quarters?
Have him bought here, under guard if necessary, but get him. I'll be responsible.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: Zoe leaves.

Dialogue.Line: Jarvis was right about one thing, Doctor. These Cybermen of yours can't just walk into the Wheel, you know.
They will find a way.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: Laleham and Vallance are space walking back to the Wheel trailing the crate behind them.
Lernov is in charge of the shift and Casali is reporting to Earth.

Dialogue.Line: Rain belts block normal. That completes the advance weather information, Earth Central. This is Space Station W 3 signing out.
Thank you, W 3. Thanks for the good news. Signing out.
Survey party calling in. Yes, come in survey party.
Coming in to loading bay, Control.
Ask why. Airlock five is all ready.
Is anything wrong? Airlock five is ready for you.
We found a whole crate of Bernalium on the rocket. Bringing it over with us. Approval please, Control.
This'll buck the old man up a bit.
Yes. I'll go check.
Just checking with control, Armand. Await confirmation. BENNETT [on monitor]: Yes?

Survey party report a find of Bernalium. They are bringing it over from the rocket. Can I give them the go-ahead? BENNETT [on monitor]: Somebody's using their brains as last. Yes, we need it badly. Good work, good work.
All right, Enrico.
Hello, survey party. All clear on the cargo now. I'm clearing the loading bay for your arrival.
Close off airlock five and clear loading bay.
Well, that's it, all right.
What you call Billy Bug?
Yes.
You're sure about this?
I'm definite. I thought I'd come across some strange space creature.
It's an alien machine. Destructive. Capable of killing.
It seemed like a space rodent. Look, I know you all think I'm crazy, but
Of course not, Bill. After all, you discovered space flora out here. When you found the Cybermat you obviously thought that it was space fauna.
Yes, it's a pity you didn't tell somebody sooner.
Maybe so, Doc, but look at what happened when I did tell the old man.
Yes.
I'd better take you back, Bill. I've got some new calculations to do on those meteorites. Half of the space fleet might be flying straight into them.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: Zoe and Duggan leave.

Dialogue.Line: Meteorites. Yes. Now the Cybermats must have sent in to destroy the laser gun but
They nearly did.
What?
Well, I assume they did. They seem to have taken a liking to all the stock of Bernalium on board. The laser needs constant supplies of Bernalium rods.
You see, Jamie.
I see right enough. If I haven't put the laser out of action, the Cybermats would have.
Yes, but why?
It's obvious. Put the Wheel out of action and make it defenceless.
But the Wheel must have other defences?
Magnetic field deflectors. The meson shield. They can counter-act small meteorites.
No, I think the Bernalium was destroyed for another purpose, but what? What?

Dialogue.Stage Direction: Laleham and Vallance have entered the loading bay with the crate. The main doors close and the bay is pressurised.

Dialogue.Line: Progress readings on the star Hercules 208 in Messier 13. Radar computer reading
What are you doing?
Bank A 208 point 16, Bank B 321 point 64. Lateral grid
Are you talking to yourself? ZOE: James Robert McCrimmon, do you realise what you have done?
What have I done?
Well, I was recording some very important readings, and now you're on my tape.
Eh?
Progress readings on the star Hercules 208 in Messier 13.
How did you do that without moving your lips?
Radar computer reading
What are you doing?
Bank A 208 point 16, Bank B 321 point 64. Lateral grid
Are you talking to yourself?
Sorry. Have I ruined it?
No, not really.
Is there anything you want?
No, I'm all right.
Well, I've got some calculations to do on those new readings.
Aye, everybody's so busy. Not that they'd talk to me anyway.
Well, you did get off to a bad start.
You mean ruining the laser. Aye, I suppose I did. Anyway, I had to do that.
Why?
Well, er, well, I can't really tell you.
Would you hold that light still, Flannigan.
My arm's getting tired.
Oh, you are a great help.
Just another few seconds, sir.
Would you get me that driver over there. Come on, hurry up. Right. Now, my beauty.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: Bennett enters.

Dialogue.Line: How's it going?
Oh, hello, sir. All right, Penny. Well, the boys could do with a break. They've worked non-stop.
I'm giving you Bill Duggan, No reason why he can't make himself useful. You others take a break. Keep up the good work.
Right sir.
Yes.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: Bennett leaves, Duggan enters.

Dialogue.Line: Oh boy, am I glad to see you, Bill.
How's it look?
Oh, we just had a bit of luck. The central deployment complex didn't get any plastic.
Oh, that's great. What about the Bernalium?
Oh, I haven't got around to that yet. Go on, you two, hop it.
Well, if it's all the same with you, sir, we'll just grab a snack and be back in five minutes.
You'll take forty five minutes and like it.
Right.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: The engineers leave.

Dialogue.Line: What about you? You look done in.
Oh, I can't leave you on your own. It needs at least two to handle this thing.
Some people have all the luck. The Controller said you needed some help. Of course, I have only done two watches in a row.
Congratulations. I've done three.
Oh, go and shove off, Leo. Chang and I can handle this.
Well, I
Come on, I know how to get to the Bernalium, don't I?
It's an extraordinary X-ray.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: The Doctor's skull, not the Cybermat.

Dialogue.Line: Extraordinary? Extraordinary?
I dare say your head'll ache for a quite a while yet but at least there's no damage.
Oh, I'm so glad there is no damage. Miss Corwyn.
Mrs.
Oh. Oh, forgive me.
My husband died in the asteroid belt three years ago.
Oh. I'm so sorry.
My name's Gemma.
Gemma. How nice. Gemma, tell me. Tell me about the Controller, Jarvis.
Tell you what?
He's a strange man to be in a position like this.
In ordinary circumstances. no.
Are there any ordinary circumstances in space?
Jarvis is simply a man who can't accept phenomena outside the laws of physics.
Yes, that's a very accurate
Were you going to say diagnosis?
You're very perceptive.
You see in this failing of his a medical weakness.
Don't you?
Normally he's more than capable of commanding this station. It's a continuous and merciless responsibility.
Exactly. One does wonder what a man like that will do when faced with a problem for which he has no solution.
I must confess I've been concerned. Jarvis shows signs of blocking off his mind. He just can't face the truth.
Everything in order here?
Well
Yes, yes. I can see it is. Good, good.
But you need rest. You really shouldn't get up yet.
Of course I have to get up.
Can you persuade him to rest?
Oh, it's no good trying to stop him.
But it's much too soon.
Now, Gemma, be reasonable. I know the dangers. The Cybermen need to colonise. They must have the treasures of Earth.
You can't leave this room. Jarvis has given orders.
He's not in control of himself.
I'm sorry, Doctor. I can't countermand any orders the Controller's issued.
He's as stubborn as you are.
(to guard) Everything in order here? Good. Good.
Up and about again, eh? That's better. I've done the tour, Gemma. Everything's running like clockwork.
Fine. I'd like to talk to you about the rocket.
Yes, everything's going very well. Very well indeed. You must want to stretch your legs. Get someone to take you round.
Oh. Oh, thank you. You will tell the guard, won't you?
(to guard) Off you go. Everything's in order here.
Jarvis.
You might want to make a note about morale, Gemma. It's excellent. Never been better.
But
Yes, there's nothing we can't handle. Nothing. Tired now. Turn in, I suppose, and get some sleep. Yes, that's good. I'll need you first watch. Yes, keep up the good work. Keep up the good work.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: Duggan is inspecting some of the remaining Bernalium rods.

Dialogue.Line: These are no good anyway. They're covered in plastic.
Laleham and Vallance bought back a load of Bernalium from the rocket.
Well, just don't stand there, go and grab a dozen sticks. With a bit of luck, we can replace these and reassemble in a couple of hours. Well, go on, chop-chop.
I'm on my way.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: Change goes down the steps to the empty bay. The crate has been unpacked and the boxes of Bernalium are next to it. Chang picks one up and is about to leave when he notices that the crate is not as it should be. He lifts a board from the false bottom and looks inside, but it is empty. A metallic hand grabs his shoulder. Chang twists away and throws the Bernalium at the Cyberman, making it stagger. The second Cyberman appears with Laleham and Vallance.

Dialogue.Line: Help me!

Dialogue.Stage Direction: Chang runs for the steps, but the Cybermen zap him with energy from their chest units. Laleham and Vallance each pick up a box of Bernalium and leave as the Cybermen dispose of Chang.
An instrument panel comes to life.

Dialogue.Line: Enrico?
Oh, hello, Leo.
Hello, Chief.
Have you had notice of anybody using the waste incinerator in the loading bay?
No, I don't think so. I'll check.
What's the problem?
Somebody just used the incinerator in the loading bay, that's all.
No, no, there's nothing here.
You'd better put it in the log, Tanya. Somebody's for the high jump.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: Laleham and Vallance enter with their boxes.

Dialogue.Line: Hello, boys. Hey, good on you. Where's Chang?
Cut his hand. He's gone to the Medical bay.
Trust him.
Anything to be done?
Yeah, you can open up a box of rods. Got this job licked. I just hope the rods are the right dimensions, that's all.
They are.
Since when have you been a expert?
The lasers have to be made operative or the meteorites will destroy the Wheel.
No. Well why do you think I'm sweating my back off here? Here, what's up with him?
They're the right ones.
Yes, so they are. You must be psychic. But don't tell the old man. He doesn't believe in extra sensory perception.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: Duggan puts a rod into the capacitator.

Dialogue.Line: Hey, this is perfect. Marvellous!
When will the repair be finished?
It won't be done at all if you keep nattering.
The meteorites must not harm the Wheel.

That storm really worries you, doesn't it? Well, don't let it, don't let it. It'll be a close call but I reckon to have this laser ready and in operation in six to seven hours. So you can sleep in your beds like babies, the pair of you. Daddy won't let anything happen to you.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: Behind Duggan's back, Vallance opens the door and lets a Cyberman in.

Dialogue.Line: Now, if you really want to make yourself useful.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: Duggan turns and sees the Cyberman, which uses its hypnosis beam on him.

Dialogue.Line: The Wheel must be protected from the meteorites. We will assemble your laser defence rays. You will go to Central Control.
Central Control.
The Operations Room. CYBERMAN 1: These are your orders.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: Doctor Corwyn is reading Bennett's medical file when Zoe enters.

Dialogue.Line: Oh, Zoe, it's you. What do you want?
Well, it's rather difficult to explain.
What is it?
Well, I've done a report. Some calculations I've been doing. I was ordered to forget them.
Ordered? By whom? What report?
My calculations on the orbital path of the meteorite storm. I found a new element which indicated a critical state and I reported my findings to the Controller.
And he ignored them.
Yes. Well, you don't sound very surprised.
No.
Well, he said it was all perfectly normal, but it isn't.
He's getting worse.
Is he ill?
I don't know yet.
Well, if he is he's chosen a rather inconvenient time, hasn't he?
Do you ever feel anything emotional, Zoe?
Emotional? Do you know, that's the second time I've been asked that in the last few hours. Leo Ryan said that I was all brains and no heart.
Yes, it's your training. I shouldn't worry about it.

Oh, but I do. I don't want to be thought of as a freak. Leo said I was like a robot, a machine. I think he's right. My head's been pumped full of facts and figures which I reel out automatically when needed, but, well, I want to feel things as well.
Good. Unfortunately the parapsychology unit at the City tends to ignore this aspect in its pupils. Some of them never fully develop their human emotions.
You don't think I'll be like that, do you?
No. No, you seemed to have survived their brain-washing techniques remarkably well.
Oh, good.
Now, about these calculations of yours.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: The Doctor is getting a tour.

Dialogue.Line: And this last one is how we check everything.
I see.
Yes, anything that uses energy on the Wheel, however small, is registered on this wall. From a coffee-grinder upwards
Do you have any coffee?
Would you like some?
I'd love some, I really would.
I have a coffee pellet. Would you like one?
That's better than nothing.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: Zoe enters and catches their attention.

Dialogue.Line: Excuse me, Doctor. Tanya.
Oh, yes, of course.
Doctor, don't forget we need that mercury stuff for the Tardis.
No, Jamie, I haven't forgotten. I'm worried about the Tardis. If I'm right and those Cybermen are. What's going on?

Dialogue.Stage Direction: There's an intense conversation happening.

Dialogue.Line: Let's find out.
What's going on, Zoe?
I've done some new calculations on the orbital path of the meteorite storm. They're heading toward us faster than we thought.
Don't you have any cheerful news?
Facts are facts, and these are indisputable.
I wouldn't dream of contradicting you. Can you repair the laser gun in time?
Well, that's not the worry, it's the Controller. I went to him with the new data on the meteorites and he just brushed the whole thing aside.
Oh dear, he's getting worse.
That what Doctor Corwyn says. He is ill, isn't he?
Why aren't you worried about the laser gun? I thought all of the Bernalium has been destroyed.
Oh no, some more turned up.
Oh good.
Yes, two of the men bought a crate of it over from the rocket.
Ah. What? What did you say?
Well, that's what Flannigan said. I met him when he was going off duty.
Gemma! Gemma, did you know about this Bernalium from the rocket?
Yes, Tanya told me.
Don't you see what it means? The Cybermen are here. They came over in that crate.
But how could our two men have bought them over?
But they didn't know what they were doing. They were just obeying orders.
The Cybermen hypnotised them?
Yes, something like that.
We're not exactly children, Doctor. All spacemen are protected against brain-control by drugs.
Yes, but a psychotropic drug is only effective against a known enemy. Have you induced repulsion in all parts of the brain yet?
No, but then there's the implanted Silenski capsules. It gives off a signal when there is an adverse influence against the wearer.
How can we check?
Tanya, I want to check the Silenski circuit.
But I shall have to activate the whole defence network.
I'll authorise the extra power.
Watch the lines. If they're steady then everything is normal.
I see.
Try this room first.
Yes, yes, please. Is that all right?

Dialogue.Stage Direction: Jamie and Zoe see Duggan.

Dialogue.Line: What's he hanging around for? I thought that he was under guard or something.
So did I. Bill, has the Controller

Dialogue.Stage Direction: Duggan ignores Zoe and goes past.

Dialogue.Line: Here, Wait a minute. Look.
Someone is affected, Doctor. You were right.
Someone in this room.
Er, can we pin it down to an individual?
I'll quarter the room off. Over there, in the direction of
No, stop him!

Dialogue.Stage Direction: Duggan smashes the communications desk with a heavy spanner. It goes bang, killing Duggan.

Dialogue.Line: He's dead. Now, now listen, listen everyone. The Cybermen are here, in this Wheel. They took over this poor fellow to stop you sending for help or signalling to Earth. Now just a minute. Gemma, you must alert the whole Wheel and you'll need something stronger than drugs to stop your people from being taken over. It doesn't matter how crude it is. A metal plate and a transistor will do. Tape them to the back of the neck. It will absorb the Cyber control signals.
I can do that.
Yes. Good.
I'll help you.
Right.
What do we do?
We're going hunting, Jamie.
Are you sure you know who's going to be hunted.
A very good question. Come on.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: The Doctor and Jamie leave.

Dialogue.Line: Can I do something?
No.
Isn't there anything I can do.
Well, all right.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: The Doctor and Jamie hide behind the crate and watch the Cyberman take one of the boxes of Bernalium then leave.

Dialogue.Line: That was close.
It's so easy.
What?
I don't understand them.
What are you talking about?
Destroying the wheel, Jamie, that's what I'm talking about. From the outside it's strong enough, but now that the Cybermen are inside, I
Yes, I see what you mean. What do you think they are planning?
Well, they obviously don't want to destroy the Wheel.
What do they want, then?
I wish I knew. The first thing we must do is to protect the people here.
How?
What's the thing which we need to survive which the Cybermen don't?
Food.
Always thinking of your stomach, aren't you. No. Air, Jamie, air. Now, I wonder how this works.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: The Doctor hits a video comm. button.

Dialogue.Line: It's the Doctor. DOCTOR [on monitor]: Hello. I think that it would be wise to lock all the air- lock doors. Can you do that?
Yes.

Leo says that he can. Why? DOCTOR [on monitor]: The Cybermen are definitely on the Wheel. Jamie and I have just seen one. They may try to interfere with the air supply. JAMIE [on monitor]: Doctor. DOCTOR [on monitor]: What? Keep this channel open. JAMIE [on monitor]: Something moved over there. Just caught the corner of my eye.
What's wrong?
I don't know.
Shall I seal off the airlocks, Gem?
Yes.
Sealing off all the airlocks.
I suppose that we can trust the Doctor?
I'm not sure why I do, but I do. Sealing off the airlocks is good common sense anyway.
There.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: It's a Cybermat. The Doctor speaks into the video comm.

Dialogue.Line: Listen to me very carefully. Do as I ask and don't delay. One of the Cybermats is very close to us. It'll tune into our brain waves at any minute.
Doctor, it's turning!
Hook up a variable audio-frequency on this channel right away. Do it at once!
Enrico, leave that.
There's a second one. Come on.
No. We don't stand a chance. They've got a range of at least ten feet.
Hurry. Please hurry.
Come on, Enrico.
All right, all right! That's it. Power! More! Come on, come on!

Dialogue.Stage Direction: The sound whine travels through the comm. circuits and builds in the loading bay. The Doctor and Jamie cover their ears and the Cybermats start veering around out of control, bumping into each other. One starts to go in tight circles until it smokes and stops while the other rushes head first into a wall to expire in a flash.

Dialogue.Line: That's enough, Enrico.
We're coming back as fast as we can. This is what you've saved us from.
What that's thing?
It's a Cybermat. DOCTOR [on monitor]: Exactly.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: Meanwhile, in the Power room, a Cyberman uses a portable communicator to contact the Mother ship and the Cyber-Planner.

Dialogue.Line: Leo. There's an energy reading from the power house.
It's not coming off our power source, that's for sure. Let's check it out.
All Cybermats have been destroyed. PLANNER [on monitor]: Destroyed? By what method.
They have used high-current phase contrast. PLANNER [on monitor]: One human has knowledge beyond our predictions. Report.
The X-ray laser machine is repaired. PLANNER [on monitor]: And operative?
Yes. In stage of operation. PLANNER [on monitor]: Communication beam to Earth?
Attacked and damaged. PLANNER [on monitor]: Phase six.
Yes. PLANNER [on monitor]: The space station is to be taken over. Complete Phase six.
Workshop. Workshop, will you come in please?
Well, Bill Duggan knew the right spot okay.
What about radar?
Radar's fine but the radio's kaput.
When's the next check to Earth Central?
Oh three hundred. Two hours time.
Set up a check on the first wave of the meteorites.
I don't see the point. We haven't got a laser to knock them out with.
Don't be pessimistic, Enrico. They may not have a direct course onto us. Anything can happen.
Everything is.
Blimey, you'd think we are alone on the Wheel. I can't raise anybody.
Have you told Gemma?
She's got her hands full enough as it is.
Jarvis? Jarvis, look at the creature. Show it to him, Zoe.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: Zoe holds up an inanimate Cybermat.

Dialogue.Line: No. No, it's not true. It's not true.
All right, Zoe, put it away somewhere. Complete withdrawal. Loss of effect.
Not necessary complete. Catatonic features certainly.
I can try ECT. He could be shocked back to normal.
Is the equipment here?
No, it's in the Medical bay.
Oh, I wouldn't advise moving him. You've thrown a magnetic forcefield round this section?
Yes.
Enough to keep the Cybermen out?
Enough to keep anything out. The crew have been warned. Oh.
No, it's no good. You're second in command. You must take over.
Take over what? We're invaded. We have no contact with Earth, we're in the path of meteorites. Take over what? How do we fight without the laser?

Dialogue.Stage Direction: On the other side of the room.

Dialogue.Line: How is he?
Hopeless.
Well, that's just fine.
He's just closed himself away.
Well, who's the second in command?
Doctor Corwyn.
At least she's all right.
Yes, although what she can do, I don't know.
Oh, there is something you don't know, then.
There's too much I don't know. I was trained to believe logic and calculation would provide me with all the answers. Well, I'm just beginning to realise there are questions which I can't answer.
You're just not trained for an emergency like this.
Well, that's the whole point. What good am I? I've been created for some false kind of existence where only known kinds of emergencies are catered for. Well, what good is that to me now?
Hey, we're not done yet, you know.
And if we survive? What then, Jamie? Suppose we do get ourselves out of this mess. What have I got left? A blind reliance on facts and logic.
Section Twelve. Section Twelve. Will you please come in?

Dialogue.Stage Direction: In section twelve, Oxygen Supply, a crewmember is about to answer the call when a Cyberman grabs him from behind.

Dialogue.Line: Calling Power house. Power house, will you please come in?

Dialogue.Stage Direction: As Flannigan enters, Laleham and Vallance come out of the shadows.

Dialogue.Line: Oh, it's yourself. Why don't you answer this thing. Somebody sounds a bit violent.
It's not important.
Ah, it could be the old man himself, you know. Well, is this laser working yet, is it?
It's finished.
Ah, so we're not to be riddled with the meteorites then?
No.
Well, that's great. I've a whole years leave coming to me back on Earth. Now come on.
Don't touch that.
You just can't ignore it. What is it? What's the matter with you two, hey?
Just do as you're told.
Hey now, have you both gone mad or what?

Dialogue.Stage Direction: Vallance points a gun at Flannigan.

Dialogue.Line: Don't point that thing at me, laddie.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: Flannigan knocks the gun from Vallance's hand and floors him. Laleham brandishes a crowbar.

Dialogue.Line: All right. If it's a fight you're after, I'm your man. Come on.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: Laleham swings the crowbar and misses.

Dialogue.Line: You need a few lessons in the noble and manly arts, me bucko! All right, come on!

Dialogue.Stage Direction: Laleham and Flannigan fight, and Vallance picks up his weapon. Vallance fires, missing Flannigan and killing Laleham instead. A Cyberman enters and hypnotises Flannigan.

Dialogue.Line: The Earth machine has been installed?
Yes.
A force field has been set around the Operations Control room. How is it operated?
Only from within the Operations Room.
Dispose of the body of the human.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: Zoe is giving Bennett some water.

Dialogue.Line: Come on, some more. Just a little more.
No, no more.
Don't force him. Give him whatever he wants.
Well, I'm not surprised you can't get in touch with the rest of the Wheel.
Aye, the Cybermen aren't going to sit around and do nothing.
But can they still control our people? I thought you'd
With the metal plates, you mean. Has everybody had them fitted to the back of their necks?
No, not yet. There are still some crew members without.
Well, it would be advisable to have it done.
Coming through now.
I lost them for a moment there.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: Everyone goes over to the radar screen.

Dialogue.Line: Hey, will you listen to that? Now this is a big storm, bigger than we thought.
All right, all right, don't make it worse.
We'll have to rely on the anti-matter field projectors.
Hey, you don't think the meteorites are going to bounce off them, do you? We're talking about things weighing two or three hundred tons here.
How far away are they?
See for yourself. Less than a million miles now. Closing on an elliptical path tilted ten degrees.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: The video comm. beeps.

Dialogue.Line: Well, thank goodness for that. Must be one of the other sections. FLANNIGAN [on monitor]: Power room.
Flannigan, where've you been? FLANNIGAN [on monitor]: Restoring the laser discharge piece.
What was that? FLANNIGAN [on monitor]: It has been completed.
The laser's repaired? FLANNIGAN [on monitor]: It is ready for testing now.

Great. The laser's working. Stand by to run a test. Flannigan, where have you been? I've been trying to raise you for ages. FLANNIGAN [on monitor]: There must be a fault on the line. Vallance is here with me. We are ready when you are ready.
Right.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: A hatch opens on the outer surface of the Wheel, and a laser cannon comes out.
